column4: An aerodrome, airport or airfield
An area of an airport where planes are parked, unloaded or loaded, refueled, or boarded
The bounded space, inside the airport terminal, where passengers wait before boarding their flight
The bounded space, inside the airport terminal, where passengers wait before boarding their flight
A landing area or platform for helicopters
A special aerodrome built for helicopters
A facility that supports visual navigation for aircraft
A strip of land on which aircraft can take off and land.
A spaceport (other than airport / heliport)
A route where airplanes manouevre between runways and parking areas within an aerodrome
An airport passenger building
An object that shows wind direction and speed.

Bar is a purpose-built commercial establishment that sells alcoholic drinks to be consumed on the premises. They are characterised by a noisy and vibrant atmosphere, similar to a party and usually don't sell food. See also the description of the tags amenity=pub;bar;restaurant for a distinction between these.

BBQ or Barbecue is a permanently built grill for cooking food, which is most typically used outdoors by the public. For example these may be found in city parks or at beaches. Use the tag fuel=* to specify the source of heating, such as fuel=wood;electric;charcoal. For mapping nearby table and chairs, see also the tag tourism=picnic_site. For mapping campfires and firepits, instead use the tag leisure=firepit.

Biergarten or beer garden is an open-air area where alcoholic beverages along with food is prepared and served. See also the description of the tags amenity=pub;bar;restaurant. A biergarten can commonly be found attached to a beer hall, pub, bar, or restaurant. In this case, you can use biergarten=yes additional to amenity=pub;bar;restaurant.

Cafe is generally an informal place that offers casual meals and beverages; typically, the focus is on coffee or tea. Also known as a coffeehouse/shop, bistro or sidewalk cafe. The kind of food served may be mapped with the tags cuisine=* and diet=*. See also the tags amenity=restaurant;bar;fast_food.
Drinking water is a place where humans can obtain potable water for consumption. Typically, the water is used for only drinking. Also known as a drinking fountain or bubbler.
Fast food restaurant (see also amenity=restaurant). The kind of food served can be tagged with cuisine=* and diet=*.
An area with several different restaurant food counters and a shared eating area. Commonly found in malls, airports, etc.
Ice cream shop or ice cream parlour. A place that sells ice cream and frozen yoghurt over the counter
A place selling beer and other alcoholic drinks; may also provide food or accommodation (UK). See description of amenity=bar and amenity=pub for distinction between bar and pub
Restaurant (not fast food, see amenity=fast_food). The kind of food served can be tagged with cuisine=* and diet=*.
Campus or buildings of an institute of Further Education (aka continuing education)
Driving School which offers motor vehicle driving lessons
For children too young for a regular school (also known as preschool, playschool or nursery school), in some countries including afternoon supervision of primary school children.
Language School
A public library (municipal, university, …) to borrow books from.
School and grounds - primary, middle and seconday schools
An university campus: an institute of higher education
Parking for bicycles
Alat umum untuk perbaikan sepeda swalayan, bisanya di pinggir jalan; tidak ada pelayana
Rent a bicycle
Rent a Boat
Share a Boat
May also be tagged as public_transport=station.
Rent a car
Share a car
Wash a car
Government vehicle inspection
Charging facility for electric vehicles
Ferry terminal/stop. A place where people/cars/etc. can board and leave a ferry.
Petrol station; gas station; marine fuel; … Streets to petrol stations are often tagged highway=service.
A container that holds grit or a mixture of salt and grit.
Parking for motorcycles
Car park. Nodes and areas (without access tag) will get a parking symbol. Areas will be coloured. Streets on car parking are often tagged highway=service and service=parking_aisle.

An entrance or exit to an underground or multi-storey parking facility. Group multiple parking entrances together with a relation using the tags type=site and site=parking. Do not mix with amenity=parking.
A single parking space. Group multiple parking spaces together with a relation using the tags type=site and site=parking. Do not mix with amenity=parking.
A place where taxis wait for passengers.
an ATM or cash point
a bank (for a bank that also has an ATM, it is preferred that a separate node for each ATM is added)
Bureau de change, currency exchange, Wechsel, cambio – a place to change foreign bank notes and travellers cheques
A place where a baby can be, out of necessity, anonymously left to be safely cared for and perhaps adopted.
A medium-sized medical facility or health centre.
A dentist practice / surgery.
A doctor's practice / surgery.
A hospital providing in-patient medical treatment. Often used in conjunction with emergency=* to note whether the medical centre has emergency facilities (A&E (brit.) or ER (am.))
Discouraged tag for a home for disabled or elderly persons who need permanent care. Use amenity=social_facility + social_facility=nursing_home now.
Pharmacy: a shop where a pharmacist sells medications
A facility that provides social services: group & nursing homes, workshops for the disabled, homeless shelters, etc.
A place where a veterinary surgeon, also known as a veterinarian or vet, practices.
A venue where a variety of arts are performed or conducted
An establishment specifically dedicated to prostitution
A gambling venue with at least one table game(e.g. roulette, blackjack) that takes bets on sporting and other events at agreed upon odds.
A place where films are shown (US: movie theater)
A place mostly used for local events, festivities and group activities; including special interest and special age groups. .
A fountain for cultural / decorational / recreational purposes.
A place for gambling, not being a shop=bookmaker, shop=lottery, amenity=casino, or leisure=adult_gaming_centre.
A place to drink and dance (nightclub). The German word is "Disco" or "Discothek". Please don't confuse this with the German "Nachtclub" which is most likely amenity=stripclub.
A planetarium.
A street furniture containing books. Take one or leave one.
A place for free and not-for-profit activities.
A place that offers striptease or lapdancing (for sexual services use amenity=brothel).
TV radio or recording studio
A club where people meet to have a party and group sex.
A theatre or opera house. Use amenity=cinema for movie theaters.
A facility where you, paying a fee, can bring your animal for a limited period of time (e.g. for holidays)
A shelter that recovers animals in trouble
An oven used for baking bread and similar, for example inside a building=bakehouse.
A bench to sit down and relax a bit
A public visible clock
A place where justice is dispensed
A place where dead human bodies are burnt
A dive center is the base coordinate where sports divers usually start scuba diving or make dive guided trips at new locations.
An embassy, consulate or diplomatic office. Also see office=diplomatic
A station of a fire brigade
Deprecated. For campfires and firepits, see Tag:leisure=firepit
A (smaller) place of burial, often you'll find a church nearby. Large places should be landuse=cemetery instead.
Do no use, leisure=fitness_centre is preferred! A place which houses exercise equipment for the purpose of physical exercise.
A hunting stand
A place whose principal role is providing internet services to the public.
A public kitchen in a facility to use by everyone or customers
Outdoor foot bath facility. Usually this is a pool with cold water and handrail. Popular in German speaking countries.
A place where trade is regulated, e.g. a square.
Monastery is the coordinate of a monastery or a building in which monks and nuns live.
Photo Booth – A stand to create instant photo.
A church, mosque, or temple, etc. Note that you also need religion=*, usually denomination=* and preferably name=* as well as amenity=place_of_worship. See the article for details.
A police station
A box for the reception of mail. Alternative mail-carriers can be tagged via operator=*
Post depot or delivery office, where letters and parcels are collected and sorted prior to delivery.
Post office building with postal services
A prison
A coordinate where the public may bathe in common, etc. japanese onsen, turkish bath, hot spring
A generic public building. Don't use! See office=government.
National Park Visitor Headquarters
Recycling facilities (bottle banks, etc.). Combine with recycling_type=container for containers or recycling_type=centre for recycling centres.
A place for depositing human waste from a toilet holding tank.
Deprecated. For sauna use: leisure=sauna
A small shelter against bad weather conditions. To additionally describe the kind of shelter use shelter_type=*.
Public shower or bath.
Public telephone
Public toilets (might require a fee)
Building where the administration of a village, town or city may be located, or just a community meeting place
A machine selling goods – food, tickets, newspapers, etc. Add type of goods using vending=*
A single small container for depositing garbage that is easily accessible for pedestrians.
A place where canal boaters, caravaners, etc. can dispose of rubbish (trash/waste).
A waste transfer station is a coordinate that accepts, consolidates and transfers waste in bulk.
Place where water is contained and animals can drink
Place where you can get large amounts of drinking water
All commonly used values according to Taginfo
A road side or median barrier made of steel wire ropes mounted on weak posts.
A fortification used to defend settlements in ancient to modern times.
A man made ditch or trench to prevent access to the other side.
A freestanding structure designed to restrict or prevent movement across a boundary, generally distinguished from a wall by the lightness of its construction.
A rail, typically metal, designed to keep vehicles within their roadway and prevent dangerous collisions
A rail designed to be grasped by the hand so as to provide stability or support.
A line of closely spaced shrubs and tree species, which form a barrier or mark the boundary of an area.
A stone edging to a pavement or raised path.
A structure that holds back soil or rock from a building, structure or area.
A freestanding structure, designed to restrict or prevent movement across a boundary, typically made from solid brick, concrete or rocks, and almost always built so that it is opaque to vision.
A boundary representing official reservation boundaries of recognized aboriginal / indigenous / native peoples.

An administrative boundary. Subdivisions of areas/territories/jurisdictions recognised by governments or other organisations for administrative purposes. These range from large groups of nation states right down to small administrative districts and suburbs, as indicated by the 'admin_level=*' combo tag.
Historic administrative boundaries, temporarily kept in OSM, along with start_date=* and end_date=* to specify dates of effect. Requires an additional admin_level=*.
Maritime boundaries

A boundary marker, border marker, boundary stone, or border stone is a robust physical marker that identifies the start of a land boundary or the change in a boundary, especially a change in direction of a boundary. See also historic=boundary_stone
Area of outstanding natural beauty, set aside for conservation and for recreation (Other languages).
Electoral boundaries
Postal code boundaries
Protected areas, such as for national parks, marine protection areas, heritage sites, wilderness, cultural assets and similar.
All commonly used values according to Taginfo
A building arranged into individual dwellings, often on separate floors. May also have retail outlets on the ground floor.
A single-storey detached small house, Dacha.
A cabin is a small, roughly built house usually with a wood exterior and typically found in rural areas.
A single dwelling unit inhabited by family or small group sharing facilities such as a kitchen.

For a shared building, as used by college/university students (not a share room for multiple occupants as implied by the term in British English). Alternatively, use building=residential plus residential=university.

A residential building on a farm (farmhouse). For other buildings see below building=farm_auxiliary, building=barn, … If in your country farmhouse looks same as general residential house then you can tag as building=house as well. See also landuse=farmyard for the surrounding area
A building designed with separate rooms available for overnight accommodation. Normally used in conjunction with tourism=hotel for the hotel grounds including recreation areas and parking.

A dwelling unit inhabited by a single household (a family or small group sharing facilities such as a kitchen). Houses forming half of a semi-detached pair, or one of a row of terraced houses, should share at least two nodes with joined neighbours, thereby defining the party wall between the properties.
A boat used primarily as a home
A general tag for a building used primarily for residential purposes. Where additional detail is available consider using 'apartments', 'terrace', 'house' or 'detached'.
A mobile home (semi)permanently left on a single site

A single way used to define the outline of a linear row of residential dwellings, each of which normally has its own entrance, which form a terrace (row-house in North American English). Consider defining each dwelling separately using 'house'.

A building where non-specific commercial activities take place, not necessarily an office building. Consider tagging the surrounding area using landuse=commercial. Use 'retail' if the building consists primarily of shops.

A building where some industrial process takes place. Use warehouse if the purpose is known to be primarily for storage/distribution. Consider using landuse=industrial for the surrounding area and the proposed industrial=* tag to describe the industrial activity.
Small retail building.

An office building. Use building=office with office=* to describe the type of office. Consider tagging the surrounding area using landuse=commercial. Use 'retail' if the building consists primarily of shops.

A building primarily used for selling goods that are sold to the public; use shop=* to identify the sort of goods sold or an appropriate amenity=* (pub, cafe, restaurant, etc.). Consider use landuse=retail for the surrounding area.
A building constructed to house a self-service large-area store.
A building primarily used for the storage or goods or as part of a distribution system.
A building that was built as a cathedral. Used in conjunction with amenity=place_of_worship, religion=*, denomination=* and landuse=religious for the cathedral grounds where it is in current use.
A building that was built as a chapel. Used in conjunction with amenity=place_of_worship, religion=*, denomination=* and landuse=religious for the chapel grounds where it is in current use.
A building that was built as a church. Used in conjunction with amenity=place_of_worship, religion=* , denomination=* and landuse=religious for the church grounds where it is in current use.
A mosque. Used in conjunction with amenity=place_of_worship, religion=*, denomination=* and landuse=religious for the grounds where it is in current use.
Unspecific religious building. Prefer more specific values if possible.

A building that was built as a shrine. Used in conjunction with amenity=place_of_worship, religion=*, denomination=* and landuse=religious for the grounds where it is in current use. Small buildings should consider historic=wayside_shrine.
A building that was built as a synagogue. Used in conjunction with amenity=place_of_worship, religion=*, denomination=* and landuse=religious for the grounds where it is in current use.
A building that was built as a temple. Used in conjunction with amenity=place_of_worship, religion=*, denomination=* and landuse=religious for the grounds where it is in current use.
A building that was built as a bakehouse (i.e. for baking bread). Often used in conjunction with another node amenity=baking_oven and oven=wood_fired.

For any civic amenity, for example amenity=community_centre, amenity=library, amenity=toilets, leisure=sports_centre, leisure=swimming_pool, amenity=townhall etc. Use amenity=* or leisure=* etc. to provide further details. See building=public as well.
For government buildings in general, including municipal, provincial and divisional secretaries, government agencies and departments, town halls, (regional) parliaments and court houses.
A building which forms part of a hospital. Use amenity=hospital for the hospital grounds.
For any generic kindergarten buildings. Buildings for specific uses (sports halls etc.) should be tagged for their purpose. Use amenity=kindergarten for the perimeter of the kindergarten grounds.
A public building. Don't use amenity=public_building.
For any generic school buildings. Buildings for specific uses (sports halls etc.) should be tagged for their purpose. Use amenity=school for the perimeter of the school grounds.
A toilet block.
A building constructed to be a train station building, including buildings that are abandoned and used nowadays for a different purpose.

A building related to public transport. You will probably want to tag it with proper transport related tag as well, such as public_transport=station. Note that there is a special tag for train station buildings - building=train_station.
A university building. Use amenity=university for the whole university area.
An agricultural building used for storage and as a covered workplace.
A conservatory is a building or room having glass or tarpaulin roofing and walls with comfortable inventory and exotic plants.
A cowshed (cow barn, cow house) is a building for housing cows, usually found on farms.
A building on a farm that is not a dwelling (use 'farm' or 'house' for the farm house).
A greenhouse is a glass or plastic covered building used to grow plants. Use landuse=greenhouse_horticulture for an area containing multiple greenhouses
A stable is a building where horses are kept.
A sty (pigsty, pig ark, pig-shed) is a building for raising domestic pigs, usually found on farms.
The main stand, usually roofed, commanding the best view for spectators at racecourses or sports grounds.
A sports pavilion usually with changing rooms, storage areas and possibly an space for functions & events. Avoid using this term for other structures called pavilions by architects (see [W] Pavilion)
A building that was built as a riding hall.
A building that was built as a sports hall.
A building constructed to be a stadium building, including buildings that are abandoned and used nowadays for a different purpose.
A hangar is a building used for the storage of airplanes, helicopters or space-craft. Consider adding aeroway=hangar, when appropriate.
A hut is a small and crude shelter. Note that this word has two meanings - it may be synonym of building=shed, it may be a residential building of low quality.
A shed is a simple, single-storey structure in a back garden or on an allotment that is used for storage, hobbies, or as a workshop.

A carport is a covered structure used to offer limited protection to vehicles, primarily cars, from the elements. Unlike most structures a carport does not have four walls, and usually has one or two.
A garage is a building suitable for the storage of one or possibly more motor vehicle or similar. See building=garages for larger shared buildings. For an aircraft garage, see building=hangar.
A building that consists of a number of discrete storage spaces for different owners/tenants. See also building=garage.
Structure purpose-built for parking cars.
A digester is a bioreactor for the production of inflatable biogas from biomass.
Service building usually is a small unmanned building with certain machinery (like pumps or transformers).

A transformer tower is a characteristic tall building comprising a distribution transformer and constructed to connect directly to a medium voltage overhead power line. Quite often the power line has since been undergrounded but the building may still serve as a substation. If the building is still in use as a substation it should additionally be tagged as power=substation + substation=minor_distribution.
A water tower
A hardened military building. Also use military=bunker.

A building used as a bridge. Can also represent a gatehouse for drawbridges. See also bridge=yes for highway=*. Don't use this tag just for marking bridges (their outlines). For such purposes use man_made=bridge.
Used for buildings under construction. Use construction=* to hold the value for the completed building.
A structure that consists of a roof with open sides, such as a rain shelter, and also gas stations

According to meaning of building=* should be used for building constructed as ruins (for example sham ruins in an English landscape garden). Frequently used incorrectly, for house, a village or other building abandoned (despite that abandoned house is still building=house).
Use this value where it is not possible to determine a more specific value.
All commonly used values according to Taginfo, generally building types
A place where engines and tools for agricultural use are planned and constructed.
A workplace for fresh bakery goods. No shop.
A person weaving baskets
A workplace of a beekeeper (apiarist)
A place where a blacksmith forges tools, horseshoes, etc. from iron.
A place where boats are planned and constructed
A workplace for physically assembling a book from a number of sheets of paper.
A dedicated building for the making of beer.
A workplace or office of a tradesman who performs structural alterations and additions to buildings.
A person who makes fine wooden furniture
A workplace or office of carpenters that work with timber to construct, install and maintain buildings, furniture, and other objects.
A carpet layer is a tradesmen who specializes in laying carpets
A workplace or office of one who prepares customized meals for takeout, or provides prepared meals or supplies to a group at social gatherings
A workplace or office of a person who cleans chimneys for a living.
A workplace or office of a clockmaker that is building, repairing or engraving clocks of all sorts.
A place where the set of food items that are rich in sugar, any one or type of which is called a confection is produced.
A person or company that manufacture of containers and vessels mainly made of wood.
A workplace for dental technician
An establishment for distilling, especially for distilling alcoholic liquors.
Dressmaker is a person who makes custom clothing for women, such as dresses, blouses, and evening gowns.
Repair shops and service centers which provides repair of computers, phones, appliance etc.
Needlework or textile artist
A person or company that works with electricity or electrical systems.
A workplace or office of an engraver.
A workplace or office of a floorer.
A workplace or office of a garden designer or a landscape gardener.
A place where residential, commercial, and artistic glass is selected, cut, installed, replaced, and removed
A device that breaks solid materials into smaller pieces by grinding, crushing, or cutting. The aftermath is powdered product, not liquid extract like oil mill.
A place where useful and decorative devices are made completely by hand or using only simple tools
A workplace or office of an HVAC system designer (Heating, Ventilating, and Air Conditioning)
A workplace or office of a person who does thermal insulation in buildings.
A place where necklaces, rings, brooches, earrings and bracelets and other personal adornments are created or repaired.
An artisan who builds things by joining pieces of wood, particularly furniture or ornamental work.
A place where keys can be duplicated from originals.
A place where locks and keys are created or repaired.
Workplace or office of a person who work with metal. This applies to: planning, construction, trade, repair.
A place where coins and medals are hand crafted.
A craftsman creating musical instruments
A mill designed to crush or bruise oil-bearing seeds, such as linseed or peanuts, or other oil-rich vegetable material.
A place where lenses for the correction of a person's vision are designed, fitted and dispensed.
Organ building is the profession of designing, building, restoring and maintaining pipe organs.
A workplace or office of a house painter which is a tradesman responsible for the painting and decorating of buildings.
A workplace or office of a parquet layer.
A workplace or office of a person who takes photographs using a camera.
A place where photos taken on a film or digital images are transformed into a more permanent form, often on paper or plastic foil.
A piano tuner or technician. A professional that tunes, regulates and makes the maintenance of pianos. Most of them repair simple problems and some restore a whole piano.
A workplace or office of a tradesman who works with plaster, such as forming a layer of plaster on an interior wall or plaster decorative moldings on ceilings or walls.
A workplace or office of a skilled tradesperson who specializes in (drinking) water supply, sewage and drainage systems
A place where earthenware, stoneware and porcelain and other ceramic ware is made by potters.
Printer
A producer of fine art prints.
A workplace or office of a person who makes masts, yards, sails, and cordage for sailboats and sailing ships.
A workplace or office of a tradesman who is specialized in roof covering and sealing.
A place where saddles or accessories for cars and boats are produced or repaired.
A workplace or office of sailmakers who cleans, repairs and makes sails.
A sawmill is a facility where logs are cut into timber
A workplace or office of a tradesman who builds temporary structure used to support people and material in the construction or repair of buildings and other large structures.
A place where sculptures are made.
A place where shoes, boots, sandals, clogs and moccasins are created, repaired or altered to fit personal needs.
Signmaker
A workplace of a company that builds stands/booths for fairs.
A place where rough pieces of rock are shaped into accurate geometrical shapes.
A place where sun protection is made, repaired, or delivered for assembly, especially awnings and shutters.
A place where clothing is made, repaired, or altered professionally, especially suits and men's clothing.
A workplace or office of a person who lays tiles on floors, swimming pools and such.
A person who makes and repairs things made of light-coloured metal, particularly tinware.
A workplace of a company that builds complex tools, machine tools, moulds, gauges,... .
A workplace or office of a turner.
A place where furniture, especially seats are provided with padding, springs, webbing, and fabric or leather covers.
A watchmaker is an artisan who makes and repairs watches. Today due to industrial production they mostly repair watches.
A workplace of someone constructing windows
A place where wine is produced
A ambulance station is a structure or other area set aside for storage of ambulance vehicles, medical equipment, personal protective equipment, and other medical supplies.
Defibrillator, an external and portable electronic device that diagnoses and can correct arrhythmia of the heart automatically (aka Automated External Defibrillator, AED)
Preselected flat area for a helicopter to land in an emergency situation
to mark the entrance to an emergency ward
a point to which firefighters can connect a pressurized water source
A device used for notifying a fire department of a fire.
A fire extinguisher is an active fire protection device used to extinguish or control small fires, often in emergency situations.
A wildland firefighting tool also called a swatter or a beater. It is designed for extinguishing minor fires in rural areas such as heaths.
A high-pressure hose used to carry water or other fire retardant (such as foam) to a fire to extinguish it.

An active fire protection measure, and a source of water provided in most urban, suburban and rural areas with municipal water service to enable firefighters to tap into the municipal water supply to assist in extinguishing a fire.
A large water basin or tank for a fire department to take water.
A man made or natural pond with water for a fire department.
A preferred point to pump water off a river or other waters for a fire department.
A place where a lifeguard is on duty
The main place for lifeguard vehicles, equipment and centre of communication
A tower used by lifeguard to watch and supervise swimmers in order to prevent drownings and other dangers
A platform used by lifeguard to watch and supervise swimmers in order to prevent drownings and other dangers; not so high as tower and mostly without walls and roof
An emergency flotation device.
A mountain rescue base for a team providing search and rescue services in mountainous environments.
A designated (safe) place where people can gather or must report to during an emergency or a fire drill
A sign number which can be used to define your current position in case of an emergency
Emergency telephone
A loud noise maker, such as an air raid siren or a tornado siren.
Any ice formed accumulation of unconsolidated glacial debris
A place where the bedrock or superficial deposits previously covered under the soil have become locally exposed
A palaeontological site.
A restricted access major divided highway, normally with 2 or more running lanes plus emergency hard shoulder. Equivalent to the Freeway, Autobahn, etc..
The most important roads in a country's system that aren't motorways. (Need not necessarily be a divided highway.)
The next most important roads in a country's system. (Often link larger towns.)
The next most important roads in a country's system. (Often link towns.)
The next most important roads in a country's system. (Often link smaller towns and villages)

The least important through roads in a country's system – i.e. minor roads of a lower classification than tertiary, but which serve a purpose other than access to properties. (Often link villages and hamlets.)
Roads which serve as an access to housing, without function of connecting settlements. Often lined with housing.
The link roads (sliproads/ramps) leading to/from a motorway from/to a motorway or lower class highway. Normally with the same motorway restrictions.
The link roads (sliproads/ramps) leading to/from a trunk road from/to a trunk road or lower class highway.
The link roads (sliproads/ramps) leading to/from a primary road from/to a primary road or lower class highway.
The link roads (sliproads/ramps) leading to/from a secondary road from/to a secondary road or lower class highway.
The link roads (sliproads/ramps) leading to/from a tertiary road from/to a tertiary road or lower class highway.
For living streets, which are residential streets where pedestrians have legal priority over cars, speeds are kept very low and where children are allowed to play on the street.

For access roads to, or within an industrial estate, camp site, business park, car park etc. Can be used in conjunction with service=* to indicate the type of usage and with access=* to indicate who can use it and in what circumstances.

For roads used mainly/exclusively for pedestrians in shopping and some residential areas which may allow access by motorised vehicles only for very limited periods of the day. To create a 'square' or 'plaza' create a closed way and tag as pedestrian and also with area=yes.

Roads for mostly agricultural or forestry uses. To describe the quality of a track, see tracktype=*. Note: Although tracks are often rough with unpaved surfaces, this tag is not describing the quality of a road but its use. Consequently, if you want to tag a general use road, use one of the general highway values instead of track.
A busway where the vehicle guided by the way (though not a railway) and is not suitable for other traffic. Please note: this is not a normal bus lane, use access=no, psv=yes instead!
For runaway truck ramps, runaway truck lanes, emergency escape ramps, or truck arrester beds. It enables vehicles with braking failure to safely stop.
A course or track for (motor) racing

A road/way/street/motorway/etc. of unknown type. It can stand for anything ranging from a footpath to a motorway. This tag should only be used temporarily until the road/way/etc. has been properly surveyed. If you do know the road type, do not use this value, instead use one of the more specific highway=* values.

For designated footpaths; i.e., mainly/exclusively for pedestrians. This includes walking tracks and gravel paths. If bicycles are allowed as well, you can indicate this by adding a bicycle=yes tag. Should not be used for paths where the primary or intended usage is unknown. Use highway=pedestrian for pedestrianised roads in shopping or residential areas and highway=track if it is usable by agricultural or similar vehicles.
For horse riders. Equivalent to highway=path + horse=designated.
For flights of steps (stairs) on footways. Use with step_count=* to indicate the number of steps

A non-specific path. Use highway=footway for paths mainly for walkers, highway=cycleway for one also usable by cyclists, highway=bridleway for ones available to horse riders as well as walkers and highway=track for ones which is passable by agriculture or similar vehicles.
Specifies that the highways has sidewalks on both sides, on one side or no sidewalk at all
For designated cycleways. Add foot=* only if default-access-restrictions do not apply.
A lane is a route that lies within the roadway
Used on ways with oneway=yes where it is legally permitted to cycle in both directions. Used together with oneway:bicycle=no.
Used on ways with oneway=yes that have a cycling lane going the opposite direction of normal traffic flow (a "contraflow" lane). Used together with oneway:bicycle=no.

A track provides a route that is separated from traffic. In the United States, this term is often used to refer to bike lanes that are separated from lanes for cars by pavement buffers, bollards, parking lanes, and curbs. Note that a cycle track may alternatively be drawn as a separate way next to the road which is tagged as highway=cycleway.
Used on ways with oneway=yes that have a cycling track going the opposite direction of normal traffic flow. Used together with oneway:bicycle=no.
There is a bus lane that cyclists are permitted to use.

Used on ways with oneway=yes that have a bus lane that cyclists are also permitted to use, and which go in the opposite direction to normal traffic flow (a "contraflow" bus lane). Used together with oneway:bicycle=no.

Cyclists share a lane with motor vehicles, but there are markings indicating that they should share the lane with motorists. In some places these markings are known as "sharrows" ('sharing arrows') and this is the tag to use for those.
Bus lane on both sides of the road.
For planned roads, use with proposed=* and a value of the proposed highway value.
For roads under construction. Use construction=* to hold the value for the completed road.

A small bus stop. Can be mapped more rigorously using public_transport=stop_position for the position where the vehicle stops and public_transport=platform for the place where passengers wait. See public_transport=* for more details.
A.k.a. crosswalk. Pedestrians can cross a street here; e.g., zebra crossing
Elevator
Sign number which can be used to define your current position in case of an emergency. Use with ref=NUMBER_ON_THE_SIGN
A "give way," or "Yield" sign
A calling device can be used to tell on your current position in case of an emergency. Use with ref=NUMBER_ON_THE_SIGN
Similar to roundabouts, but at the center there is either a painted circle or a fully traversable island. In case of an untraversable center island, junction=roundabout should be used.

Indicates a junction (UK) or exit (US). ref=* should be set to the exit number or junction identifier. (Some roads – e.g., the A14 – also carry junction numbers, so the tag may be encountered elsewhere despite its name)
The coordinate of a passing space
Place where drivers can leave the road to rest, but not refuel.
A fixed road-side or overhead speed camera.
A street light, lamppost, street lamp, light standard, or lamp standard is a raised source of light on the edge of a road, which is turned on or lit at a certain time every night
A service station to get food and eat something, often found at motorways
A stop sign
Lights that control the traffic
A turning circle is a rounded, widened area usually, but not necessarily, at the end of a road to facilitate easier turning of a vehicle. Also known as a cul de sac.
A toll gantry is a gantry suspended over a way, usually a motorway, as part of a system of electronic toll collection. For a toll booth with any kind of barrier or booth see: barrier=toll_booth
All commonly used values according to Taginfo
A decommissioned aircraft which generally remains in one place.
A historic structure to convey water
A place in which evidence of past activity is preserved.
The site of a battle or military skirmish in the past.
A physical marker that identifies a boundary
A historic/retired cannon. Usually found on forts or battlefields.
Used for various kinds of castles, palaces, fortresses, manors, stately homes, kremlins, shiros and other.
A fortification surrounding the bailey of a castle
A building with historical value for Christian religious activities, particularly for worship services.
A city gate within a city wall
A citywall is a fortification used to defend a city.
A historical farm, kept in it's original state.
Military fort
remains of a gallows
A marker for indicating past flood
A decommissioned locomotive which generally remains in one place
Historic manors/mansions having different use today
Small memorials, usually remembering special persons, people who lost their lives in the wars, past events or missing places.
A historic marker that shows the distance to important destinations
Building/place that was a monastery.
A memorial object, which is especially large, built to remember, show respect to a person or group of people or to commemorate an event.
Semaphore system
A pillory.
A decommissioned railway car which generally remains in one place
Remains of structures that were once complete, but have fallen into partial or complete disrepair.
Stones, boulders or bedrock with historical runic inscriptions.
A decommissioned ship/submarine which generally remains in one place
A decommissioned tank which generally remains in one place
A structure where somebody has been buried.
This property distinguishes a tower as historic
A historical cross, symbol of christian faith.
A historical shrine often showing a religious depiction.
A nautical craft that has unintentionally been sunk or destroyed.

Predominantly commerical businesses and their offices. Commercial businesses which sell goods should be catergorised as landuse=retail. Commerical businesses can sell services on site and may include private Doctor's Surgeries, and those non-government services for mental and physical health, such as a Counsellor's or Physiotherapist's practice or Veterinary. Government services and businesses should not use this tag. Commercial businesses can also include office buildings and business parks which have limited interface with the public and sell their services either on site, or externally. Commercial businesses have low amounts of public foot traffic.

A site which is under active development and construction of either a building, strucutre, including any purposeful alteration to the land or vegetation upon it. Abandoned construction projects and sites should not use this tag.
Predominantly industrial landuses such as workshops, factories, or warehouses.

Land where people reside; predominantly residential detached (single houses, grouped dwellings), or attached (apartments, flats, units) dwellings. For "Mixed-Use" areas where more than half of the land is residential, tag as residential.

Predominantly retail businesses such as shops. Retail businesses sell physical goods such as food (prepared or grocery), clothing, medicine, stationary, appliances, tools, or other similar physical items. Retail businesses have high amounts of public foot traffic. Retail businesses do not exclusively provide or sell their services. For businesses which sell services see landuse=commercial.
A piece of land given over to local residents for growing vegetables and flowers.
An area artificially graded to hold water.
Describes land scheduled for new development where old buildings have been demolished and cleared
Place for burials. You can add religion=* (values listed in the place of worship page). Smaller places (e.g. with a church nearby) may use amenity=grave_yard instead.
Protected areas (Not approved) Alternate tagging of same thing: boundary=protected_area, protected_area=*

An area used as a depot for e.g. vehicles (trains, buses or trams). Consider using rather standard landuse tags like landuse=railway, landuse=commercial, landuse=industrial, with subtag like industrial=depot.
An area of farmland used for tillage (cereals, vegetables, oil plants, flowers).

An area of land with farm buildings like farmhouse, dwellings, farmsteads, sheds, stables, barns, equipment sheds, feed bunkers, etc. plus the open space in between them and the shrubbery/trees around them.
Managed forest or woodland plantation (Other languages). Some use this to map an area of trees rather than the use of the land. See Forest.
One level buildings with boxes commonly for cars, usually made of brick and metal. Usually this area belong to garage cooperative with own name, chairman, budget, rules, security, etc.
An area of mown and managed grass. Some view this as not a landuse, see the main page landuse=grass for information.
Describes land scheduled for new development where there have been no buildings before. A greenfield is scheduled to turn into a construction site
Area used for growing plants in greenhouses
Place where waste is dumped.
A meadow or pasture.
For land areas owned/used by the military for whatever purpose
intentional planting of trees or shrubs maintained for food production
(Proposed in Proposed features/pasture:) An area of land primarily vegetated by grass, used for grazing.
An excavation created by the removal of peat.
intentional planting of plants maintaining for the production of new plants
coastal industrial area where commercial traffic is handled. Consider using landuse=industrial + industrial=port for this type of industrial area.
Surface mineral extraction
Area for railway use, generally off-limits to the general public
An open green space for general recreation, which may include pitches, nets and so on, usually municipal but possibly also private to colleges or companies
Religious territory

There was considerable confusion whether landuse=reservoir is deprecated, but it turned out to be not deprecated and landuse=reservoir is used much wider than "new" way natural=water + water=reservoir. It may be a good idea to tag the actual water body with natural=water + water=reservoir in addition or instead of landuse=reservoir. See also the approved water details proposal and pointers to discussion on talk page.
A place where sea water is evaporated to extract its salt
An area of common land, usually grass, in the centre of a village (quintessentially English – defined separately from 'common land' under the Commons Registration Act 1965 and the Commons Act 2006).
A piece of land where grapes are grown.
All commonly used values according to Taginfo
A venue with gambling machines.
A venue with pay-to-play games.
A managed beach, including within the boundary any associated facilities. Entry may also require payment of a fee.
A bandstand is an open structure where musical bands can perform concerts
A place that is used to observe wildlife, especially birds.
A place to go dancing.
A place to play disc golf
A designated area, with or without a fenced boundary, where dog-owners are permitted to exercise their pets unrestrained.
A physical adventure game in which players solve a series of puzzles using clues, hints and strategy to complete the objectives at hand.
A fire ring or fire pit, often at a campsite or picnic site
A public place for fishing
Fitness centre
An outdoor facility where people can practise typical fitness excercises
A place where flowers and other plants are grown in a decorative and structured manner or for scientific purposes.
A place where people with common interests (science, technology, ...) meet.
A facility where people practise horse riding, usually in their spare time, e.g. a riding centre. For a riding arena use the tags for pitch and equestrian sport.
A place where you can skate and play bandy or ice hockey.
A facility for mooring leisure yachts and motor boats.
A place or area where you can play miniature golf.
A protected area of importance for wildlife, flora, fauna or features of geological or other special interest.
A park, usually urban (municipal).
A table with benches for food and rest
An area designed for practising a particular sport, normally designated with appropriate markings.
A playground.
A slipway
A sports centre is a distinct facility where sports take place within an enclosed area.
A major sports facility with substantial tiered seating.
A place for supervised camps for children or teenagers conducted during the summer months
An official open-space natural place where you can swim
A swimming pool (water area only)
A track for running, cycling and other non-motorised racing such as horses, greyhounds.
An amusement park with features like water slides, recreational pools (e.g. wave pools) or lazy rivers.
A place to observe wildlife.
A type of entrance to an underground mine which is horizontal or nearly horizontal.
A structure for signalling on land and sea
A man-made structure designed to protect a shore or harbour from the sea and waves.
The outline of a bridge, grouping together all features for that bridge.
An open-sided structure that can be used with vehicles to fill and empty them.
A free standing bell tower, typically near a church.
construction to hang carpets for cleaning with the help of carpet beaters.
A tall distinctive vertical conduit for venting hot gases or smoke, normally found near power stations or large factories
A huge tower for transmitting radio applications
A stationary, permanent crane.
Cross with little historical or religion value, e.g. summit cross
A straight line cut in a forest.
Area, where most or all trees are uniformly cut down.
A place where doves are farmed or stored.
An embankment built to restrict the flow of water or other liquids
An artificial steep slope
A long pole built to hold a flag
A large container in which natural gas or town gas is stored near atmospheric pressure at ambient temperatures.
A rigid structure built from a shoreline or riverbank that interrupts water flow and limits the movement of sediment
A kiln
Tower that emits light to serve as a navigational aid at sea or on inland waterway
A mast is a vertical structure built to hold, for example, antennas.
Mineshafts are vertical tunnels.
A station that monitors something.
Tall, narrow, four-sided, tapered monument which usually ends in a pyramid-like shape at the top.
Observatory
Offshore platform
Oil well
A pier is a raised walkway over water, supported by widely spread piles or pillars.
A major pipeline carrying gas, water, oil, etc.
Pumping station
A covered reservoir is a large man-made tank for holding fresh water
A storage container for bulk material, often grains such as corn or wheat
A solid fence-like structure built across steep slopes to reduce risk and severity of (snow) avalanches
A netting fence built across steep slopes to reduce risk and severity of (snow) avalanches
A container that holds liquids or compressed gases.
A cabinet located in the street and hosting technical equipment to operate facilities such as electricity or street lights.
A surveillance camera or other type of surveillance equipment.
A triangulation pillar, geodetic vertex, or other piece of fixed equipment used by topographers.
Telescope
A tower is a building, which is higher than it is wide
A wastewater plant is a facility used to treat wastewater.
A mill driven by water power.
Structure with a water tank at an altitude to increase pressure in water network
A structural facility to access ground water, created by digging or drilling.
Publicly usable press button water tap
A place where drinking water is found and applied to the local waterpipes network.
Structure that allow animals to cross human barriers safely.
A traditional windmill
A factory or industrial production plant
A place where military planes take off and land.
A building reinforced to withstand attack
Buildings where soldiers live and work
Place of a possible access to a restricted or secured area, where civilian visitors and vehicles will be controlled by a military authority.
An exclusion zone around something like a firing range
A tag for navy bases.
Nuclear weapons test site
A military obstacle course
Military offices, e.g. general staff office, military recruitment office etc
Where soldiers practice with their weapons (firing, bombing, artillery, …)
A military training area/proving ground
Military trench
Tree-covered area (a 'forest' or 'wood')
A line of trees
A single tree
Uncultivated land covered with bushes or stunted trees.
A dwarf-shrub habitat, characterised by open, low growing woody vegetation, often dominated by plants of the Ericaceae.
Don't use, see wikipage
Natural areas where the vegetation is dominated by grasses (Poaceae) and other herbaceous (non-woody) plants.
Habitat above tree line covered with grass, dwarf shrubs and mosses.
An area with sparse or no vegetation, so that the bedrock becomes visible
Unconsolidated angular rocks formed by rockfall and weathering from adjacent rockfaces
An accumulation of rounded rock fragments on a beach or riverbed
An area covered by sand with no or very little vegetation
Area covered with mud
Any body of water, from natural such as a lake or pond to artificial like moat or canal
A natural area subject to inundation or with waterlogged ground
A permanent body of ice formed naturally from snow that is moving under its own weight.
An area of water mostly surrounded by land but with level connection to the ocean or a lake.
A piece of elevated land sticking out into the sea or large lake.
Unvegetated strip of sand, shingle or other loose material at the coast or the shore of a lake
The mean high water spring line between the sea and land (with the water on the right side of the way)
A place where ground water flows naturally from the ground
Hot spring
A spring characterized by intermittent discharge of water ejected turbulently and accompanied by steam
An opening to a sea cave which has grown landwards resulting in blasts of water from the opening due to the wave action.
The top (summit) of a hill or mountain.
An opening exposed on the earth's surface where volcanic material is emitted.
A natural depression flanked by ridges or ranges of mountains or hills
A piece of land projecting into water from a larger land mass, nearly surrounded by water
A narrow strip of land, bordered by water on both sides and connecting two larger land masses
A mountain landform with a continuous elevated crest or linear hill
A thin, almost knife-like, ridge of rock which is typically formed when two glaciers erode parallel U-shaped valleys
A vertical or almost vertical natural drop in terrain, usually with a bare rock surface
The lowest point along a ridge or between two mountain tops
A notable rock or group of rocks attached to the underlying bedrock
A single notable freestanding rock, which may differ from the composition of the terrain it lies in.
A natural depression or hole in the surface topography
An entrance to a cave
An office for an accountant.
A place where prospective parent/s may adopt a child or children.
A service-based business dedicated to creating, planning, and handling advertising.
An office for an architect or group of architects.
An office of a non-profit organisation, society, e.g. student, sport, consumer, automobile, bike association, etc…
office where a person can pledge money or property as collateral to secure the temporary release of a defendant from jail
An office of a charitable organization
An office of a private company
An office where people can go to work (might require a fee); not limited to a single employer
An office for an educational institution.
An office for an employment service.
An office for a energy supplier.
An office for an engineer or group of engineers.
A place where you can rent or buy a house.
An office of a company in the financial sector
A forestry office
An office of a foundation
An office of a person doing land surveys.
An office of a (supra)national, regional or local government agency or department
An office for tour guides, mountain guides, dive guides, etc.
The Harbourmaster's office
An office at which you can take out insurance policies.
An office for an IT specialist.
An office for a lawyer.
An office for a forwarder / hauler.
An office which offers a relocation service.
An office of a newspaper
An office for a non-government organisation.
An office for a notary public.
An office of a political party
An office of a private investigator
Office of a company, which manages a real estate property.
An office of a quasi-autonomous non-governmental organisation.
office of a community of faith
An office for research and development
An office of a person doing surveys, this can be risk and damage evaluations of properties and equipment, opinion surveys or statistics.
Fiscal authorities, tax and revenue office.
An office for a financial expert specially trained in tax law
An office for a telecommunication company
An office of an organisation offering visa assistance
The office for a water utility company or water board.
Generic tag for unspecified office type.
A nation state or other high-level national political/administrative area.
A large sub-national political/administrative area.
Used both as a broad tag for geographic or historical areas with no clear boundary and for distinct administration areas (with specific boundaries) in some countries.
A province
A district - a type of administrative division that, in some countries, is managed by local government.
A county - a geographical region of a country.
A municipality - single urban administrative division having corporate status.
The largest urban settlement or settlements within the territory.
A part in larger city grouped into administrative unit.
A part of a town or city with a well-known name and often a distinct identity.
A quarter is a named, geographically localised place within a suburb of a larger city or within a town which is bigger than a neighbourhood
A neighbourhood is a smaller named, geographically localised place within a suburb of a larger city or within a town or village
A named city block, usually surrounded by streets.
A named plot is a tract or parcel of land owned or meant to be owned by some owner.
An important urban centre, between a village and a city in size.
A smaller distinct settlement, smaller than a town with few facilities available with people traveling to nearby towns to access these.
A smaller rural community, typically with fewer than 100-200 inhabitants, and little infrastructure.
The smallest kind of settlement (1-2 households).
An individually named farm.
A separate settlement, which is located outside an officially inhabited locality and has its own addressing
One of the seven continents: Africa, Antarctica, Asia, Australia, Europe, North America, South America
A named group or chain of related islands and islets.
Any piece of land that is completely surrounded by water and isolated from other significant landmasses.
A very small island.
A named square.
A named place that has no population.
A part of an ocean.
The world's five main major oceanic divisions.
A place/industrial facility where power is generated (electricity, heat, cold water, biogas...). Individual generating units within the facility should be tagged as power=generator.

A way following the path of underground cables, such as the local 0.4 kV network between transformer stations, distribution boxes and cable connection points, or sea cables. Not to be confused with non-power supply cables such as cables for telecommunication. May be combined with voltage=*, circuits=* and coordinate=*.
A catenary mast supports system of overhead wires used to supply electricity to electricaly powered vehicle equipped with a pantograph.
Several kind of power devices used to insure of power quality and network resilience.
A freestanding electrical connection between two or more overhead wires
An HVDC converter converts electric power from high voltage alternating current (AC) to high-voltage direct current (HVDC), or vice-versa.
A device used to convert power from one form to another. Use in combination with generator:source=*, generator:method=* and generator:output=*.
A mirror of a heliostat device.
A device to protect a power line from grounding on supports

A way following the path of (overground) power cables. For minor power lines with poles and not towers, you may want to use power=minor_line. Useful combinations: voltage=*, cables=* and wires=*. Please see the respective feature pages for details.
Determines a power=line to a busbar.
A bay connects an incoming circuit to a busbar assembly.
A separate pole or pedestal sticking out of the ground, or a wall marker describing the distance to a cable or other feature.

A way following the path of (overground) minor power cables, supported by poles and not towers/pylons. (This isn't quite so simple, as sometimes larger towers are replaced by smaller poles made with a stronger material; a better distinction might be based on voltage).
Poles supporting low to medium voltage lines (power=minor_line) and high voltage lines (power=line) up to 161,000 volts (161 kV).
Power supporting structure composed of vertical legs with cables between them attached to a horizontal crossarm

A tag for electricity substations. These provide voltage step-up/step-down, switching, conditioning, etc. Substations may be large facilities (up to several acres) for very high voltage transmission lines or just small buildings or kiosks near the street for low voltage distribution lines. Useful combinations: voltage=*, substation=* and coordinate=*, see the feature page for details.
A tag for electricity switches which are devices which allow operators to power up & down lines and transformer in substations or outside.
The switchgear comprises one or more busbar assemblies and a number of bays each connecting a circuit to the busbar assembly.
Point of connection between overhead power lines to buildings or walls

For towers or pylons carrying high voltage electricity cables. Normally constructed from steel latticework but tubular or solid pylons are also commonly used. Should not be used for medium or low voltage electricity conductors carried on single wooden poles which might be tagged power=pole. See power=tower for detailed tagging of tower types.
A static device for transferring electric energy by inductive coupling between its windings. Large power transformers are typically located inside substations.
All commonly used values according to Taginfo
The position on the street or rails where a public transport vehicle stops.
The place where passengers are waiting for the public transport vehicles.
A station is an area designed to access public transport.
A relation that contains all elements of a train, subway, monorail, tram, bus, trolleybus, aerialway, or ferry stop.

The course of a former railway which has been abandoned and the track and infrastucture removed. The course may be still recognized through embankments, cuttings, bridges, tunnel and rolling or straight ways.
Railway under construction.
A section of railway which is no longer used but where the track and infrastructure remains in place. See disused:railway=* for alternative tagging.

Cable driven inclined railways. They often serve tourists, offering spectacular mountain views. However, they are also found in urban areas as a practical way to transport people up and down very steep hills (e.g. Angel's Flight in Los Angeles, Budavári Sikló in Budapest).
A higher-standard tram system, normally in its own right-of-way. Often it connects towns and thus reaches a considerable length (tens of kilometers).
Miniature railways are narrower than narrow gauge and carry passengers. They can often be found in parks.
A railway with only a single rail. A monorail can run above the rail like in Las Vegas and Disneyland or can suspend below the rail like the Wuppertal Schwebebahn (Germany).

Narrow-gauge passenger or freight trains. Narrow gauge railways can have mainline railway service like the Rhaetian Railway in Switzerland or can be a small light industrial railway. Use gauge=* to specify the actual width of rails in mm.

A railway running historic trains, usually a tourist attraction (changed to preserved from preserved_rail as "rail" is redundant). Using railway:preserved=yes is an alternate method to mark railway as preserved.
Full sized passenger or freight trains in the standard gauge for the country or state.
A city passenger rail service running mostly grade separated (see Wikipedia:rapid transit). Often a significant portion of the line or its system/network is underground.
One or two carriage rail vehicles, usually sharing motor road (Other languages).
If the railway goes over a street, waterway or other railway.
A section where the railway is significantly lower than ground level.
contact_line: a power line over the train head
A section where the railway is raised significantly higher than ground level.
The frequency with which a line is electrified. Use 0 for DC. Also see the voltage tag.
Track number
Relatively short lengths of track which switch traffic from one parallel line to another
Relatively short lengths of track, running parallel to (and connected to) a main route
Relatively short lengths of track, built to give one company or entity access to a main or branch line.
Tracks within railway company operated marshaling or maintenance yards.

Number of parallel tracks in close proximity when mapped as one single way representing all tracks. If not given means unknown and defaults to 1. In many parts of the world the tracks are being drawn out separately so that there is more detail, in which case this tag isn't used.
If the railway goes below ground. Most of subways have this tag.
The voltage with which a line is electrified. Also see the frequency tag.
A small station without switches

The position on the railway track where the train (its center) stops at a platform. This is useful for routing on long platforms where also short trains stop and on long platforms where multiple trains stop behind each other. See also public_transport=stop_area.

This is parallel to the rail line for showing where the actual platforms are. It is also to know where you can change platform and enter the station, so use footpaths to connect them. This is really useful for routing too. Use only if the platform is served by public transport.

This is parallel to the rail line for showing where the actual platforms are. It is also to know where you can change platform and enter the station, so use footpaths to connect them. This is really useful for routing too. Use in addition to public_transport=platform.
Railway passenger only station.
Railway passenger and/or cargo station. Use in addition to public_transport=station.
The entrance to a subway station, usually going from surface to underground.
A tram stop is a place where a passenger can embark / disembark a tram.
stops the train at the end of a track. see Buffer_stop.
a device used to prevent fouling of a rail track by unauthorized movements of trains or unattended rolling stock. See Derail_(railroad).
A point where pedestrians may cross.
A point where rails and roads cross.
Ground used around railways and railway-stations.
Any kind of railway signal.
Full Connections between railways (aka 'points').
Crossing rails with no interconnection.
These are used for changing the direction that part of a train is pointing in.
A semicircular building with many stalls for servicing engines.
These are used for changing trains between railways. Also known as transfer table.
A Railroad car wash
All commonly used values according to Taginfo
Cycle routes explains how to tag cycle routes.
The route a public bus service takes. See Buses.
Route for canoeing through a waterway.
Emergency evacuation routes, with direction, for various types of emergencies.
Route for fixed detour routes. Examples are Bedarfsumleitung in Germany and uitwijkroute in the Netherlands
The route a ferry takes from terminal to terminal Please make sure to add at least one node per tile (zoom level 12), better at least one every few km, so offline editors catch it with bbox requests.
Fitness trails consist of a path or course equipped with obstacles or stations distributed along its length for exercising the human body.
Hiking explains how to tag hiking routes.
Riding routes
Inline has more information on the subject.
Route of a light rail line.
Signed motorboat routes.
Mountain biking explains how to tag mtb routes.
For nordic walking routes.
For pipelines, pipeline markers, and pipeline stations.
Route of a piste (e.g., snowshoe or XC-Ski trails) in a winter sport area.
Where power lines use the same towers (the same way).
A sequence of railway ways, often named (e.g., Channel Tunnel). See Railways.
Can be used to map various road routes/long roads.
For running (jogging) routes.
For ski tracks (e.g., XC-Ski Trails com.baremaps.jdbi.User:Langläufer/Loipemap).
Train services (e.g., London-Paris Eurostar) See Railways.
See Trams for more information on tagging tram services.
All commonly used values according to Taginfo.
Shop selling alcohol to take away
Shop focused on selling bread
Shop focused on selling alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages. See also shop=alcohol.
Shop focused on selling supplies for home brewing of beer, wine and spirits (where permitted).
Shop focused on selling meat
Shop focused on selling cheese.
Shop focused on selling chocolate.
Shop focused on selling coffee.
Shop focused on selling sweets or candy
A small local shop carrying a small subset of the items you would find in a supermarket
Shop focused on selling delicatessen (fine foods, gourmet foods), possibly also fine wine. Not to be confused with the US delis.
Shop focused on selling dairy products.
Shop or roadside stand focused on selling freshly harvested farm produce
Shop focused on selling frozen food.
Shop focused on selling vegetables and fruits.
A health food shop; selling wholefoods, vitamins, nutrition supplements and meat and dairy alternatives.
Shop focused on selling ice cream to take home. See also amenity=ice_cream.
Shop focused on selling organic food. Alternatively you can use the more versatile organic=* in combination with a general shop=* key (In this case: shop=supermarket or shop=convenience).
Shop focused on selling (fresh) pasta, ravioli, etc.
Shop focused on selling baked sweets like cakes, biscuits, strudel and pies.
Shop focused on selling fish/seafood.
Shop focused on selling spices.
Shop without own building. Undesirable tagging as it conflicts with specifying shop type. Consider using street_vendor=yes for that as proposed
Shop focused on selling tea.
please use shop=alcohol + drink:wine=yes instead
Shop focused on selling drinking water.
A single large store – often multiple storeys high – selling a large variety of goods (see also shop=mall)
A store that carries a general line of merchandise. (see also shop=convenience if it sells food).
A small shop on the pavement that sells magazines, tobacco, newspapers, sweets and stamps.
A shopping mall – multiple stores under one roof (also known as a shopping centre)
Supermarket – a large store with groceries and other items
Wholesale/warehouse club or cash and carry - a store that sells items in bulk to retailers. The branch of industry can be defined with wholesale=*.
Shop focused on selling objects for babies (clothes, prams, cots, toys).
Shop focused on selling bags.
A small shopping outlet, especially one that specializes in elite and fashionable items
Shop focused on selling clothes and/or underwear (other related value in use is fashion)
Shop focused on selling fabric and other materials for the purpose of making clothes and other products, eg dress making.
Shop focused on selling fashion.
Shop focused on selling fashion accessories.
Jewellers shops.
Shop focused on selling products made out of leather.
A shop that sells sewing supplies (fabric, thread, yarn, knitting needles, sewing machines, etc.)

Not an actual shop, of course. You may want to use this tag when a shop has been closed, to avoid confusing other mappers who may not know about this (please leave a note=*). Plus, you can keep the corresponding object and simply edit it when a new shop opens on the same spot. May be confusing, a vacancy is not a shop and should not show up on maps as a shop. disused:shop=* is an alternative
